advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> NORTHSTAR BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>NorthStar brochure - Page 2 <b>EXPANSION OPTIONS</b><br><br> <b>HRAM.64</b> - High Speed 64Kb Dynamic RAM memory board with parity (up to a total of six)<br> <b>HSIO.4</b> - Four Serial Port Expansion Board (RS-232C or Current Loop).<br> <b>FPB</b> - Floating Point Arithmetic Board.<br> <b>ADC-2D</b> - Two additionaI 5 1/4 inch Double capacity floppy disk drives incorporated within a cabinet (360 Kb total capacity).<br> <b>ADC-2Q</b> - Two additionaI 5 1/4 inch Quad capacity floppy disk drives incorporated within a cabinet (720 Kb total capacity).<br> <b>HDS-5</b> - 5 1/4 inch Winchester Hard Disk 5 Mb formatted capacity.<br> <b>HDS-18</b> - 14 inch Winchester Hard Disk 18 Mb formatted capacity.<br> <b>Tape Backup</b> - 13.4 Mb Tape Backup system for HDS-18 or HDS-5.<br> <b>CRT</b> - Hazeltine 1420/Soroc 120. (Other software drivers available.)<br> <b>Printer</b> - 35 or 55 cps letter quality printer. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Gordon Dyer</b> from England </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Tony Mattson for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US AD. AUGUST 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.spies.com/~aek/orphanage.html" target="_blank">The Minicomputer Orphanage</a> website</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (DEC. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"MO5. Adventure built-in"<br> "All the world in a present"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FLYER</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.peekandpoke.org" target="_blank">www.peekandpoke.org</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982) #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>The display says: "Personal computer Pravetz 82"<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Bojidar Stefanov</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD. (JUN. 83)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> We've wired CompuPro savvy into three of the industry most potent new processor chips. The result: more performance, more quality, more reliability, and higher speed for greater throughput than ever before.<br> CPU 286 and CPU 16032 can upgrade present systems to state-of-the-art operation, or serve as powerful fundations for new systems. CPU 68K, aside from being a superd CPU board, is also the core of our system 816/68K.<br> As always, CompuPro kept an eye on the future in designing these CPUs. With a CompuPro, you don't shudder a fast-changing technology, you welcome it.<br><br> We give you brains and brawn in one box, and that's beautiful. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"With the Alice computer, you place the level where you want"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>The personal computer at the top of its form.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, JUL 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Byte Magazine</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZEALAND ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>From left to right arrow, advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> Redesigned front panel. Totally synchronous logic design. Same switch and LED arrangement as original Altair 8800. New back.lit Duralith (laminated plastic and mylar, bonded to aluminum) dress panel with multi.color graphics. New longer, flat toggle switches. Five new functions stored on front panel PROM inc1uding: DISPLAY ACCUMULATOR (displays contents of accumulator), LOAD ACCUMULATOR (loads contents of the 8 data switches (A7.AO) into accumulator), OUTPUT ACCUMULATOR (Outputs contents of accumulator to I/O device addressed by the upper 8 address switches), INPUT ACCUMULATOR (inputs to the accumulator from the I/O device), and SLOW (causes program execution at a rate of about 5 cycles per second for program debugging). <br><br> Two, 34 conductor ribbon cable assemblies. Connects front panel board to front panel interface board. Eliminates need for complicated front panel/bus wiring. <br><br> New front panel interface board buffers all lines to and from 8800b bus. <br><br> Rugged, commercial grade Optima cabinet. <br><br> Full 18 slot motherboard. <br><br> New CPU board with 8080A microprocessor and Intel 8224 clock generator and 8216 bus drivers. Clock pulse widths and phasing as well as frequency are crystal controlled. Compatible with all current Altair 8800 software and hardware!. <br><br> New, heavy duty power supply: +8 volts at 18 amps, + 18 volts at 2 amps, -18 volts at 2 amps. 110 volt or 220 volt operation (50/60 Hz). Primary tapped for either high or low line operation.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zealand</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (APR. 87) </strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SEMI-TECH BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>"With the Alice, change the level without changing the computer"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MENTA & SOFTY ADVERT (FRANCE, SEPT. 82)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> VICTOR AD #2 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In this advert, the Victor 9000 features was compared with those of four competitor computers: IBM PC, Xerox 820, Apple III and TRS-80 Model II. <br><br> Victor features was definitely higher than all of the desktop computers of the time, including the IBM PC. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT (1991)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This japanese advert indicates that there were at least 3 different models sold...</blockquote>

computer.description:
The Nec PC-8801FA replaced the PC-88FH.
This machine had really powerful sound functions. 6 FM channels could be separated into left and right. User could thus enjoy stereo sound through headphones or external speakers.
ADPCM could change sound's frequency dynamically. 256 KB of RAM were provided as sound memory buffer. It was larger than main memory.
N88 BASIC offered extended function for controlling these sound features, but not enough. Some of them couldn't be used with BASIC.
The PC-8801FA met a great success in japanese market. Thanks to Nomura Hisayuki for this information

item.description: Dual 5.25'' floppy discs unit||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> DUAL 5.25'' FLOPPY DISCS UNIT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Dual 5.25" Double-side, double-density 320 KB floppy drive unit. <br> The unit uses the 8255 parallel interface. It can be also used with PC-8001/mkII, PC-8801 Series, PC-9801/E/F/M etc.</blockquote>

computer.keyboard: Full-stroke 103 keys separate numeric keypad, function and arrow keys
computer.name: PC 8801 FA
computer.ports: Parallel printer, Mouse, RGB monitor, Serial
computer.sound: YM2608 (6 ch FM + 3 ch PSG + 6 PCM (rhythm) +1 ch 4 bit ADPCM
